body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

At a PS prompt type, type in simple math. The numbers do not show but the math symbols do, as well as the answers (see image). I have tried changing the background color and text color but the same issue occurs. I have also tried running PowerShell as admin, same issue.

### Expected behavior

```console
1+1
2
```


### Actual behavior

```console
+ 
2
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
It looks like the combination of the terminal colours and PS-Readline's tokenization.  The defaults look like this 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16209593/145796364-d696a054-8caf-4b07-99c8-de16c840cf00.png)

But if you change the terminal colours  you can make this happen.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16209593/145796551-086d4ae8-8e00-4b22-8079-5c5963ffc622.png)

My guess is in setting the blue background for the shell above (PWSH defaults to black) another colour has changed.

comments.body:
> @jhoneill Sadly no (also I noticed that even though the properties are set as shown below, and I ran Clear-Host, the background is still PowerShell blue. Not sure what that's about either):  


`Clear-Host` just clears the screen, it doesn't change what the windows console host has saved for that executable -

The one I've circled is the problem  You've clicked the radio button for "What does text with no specified colour show as"  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16209593/145858916-f59b78a9-26c3-41a3-9e4d-bc7af9d89943.png)

Compare what you have with mine. Whatever has configured that (and the title bar makes me think its the start menu short cut) has said "Bright white" - should be black

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> I think the issue here is PsReadLine controlling the colours at the console. It certainly hit me - but I just used `Set-PSReadLineOption` to set the colours I need to make the console look better.

If he does ` Get-PSReadLineOption` I'll bet he has numbercolor = Escape [97m , but those screen shots show  his console settings are redefining the colour used in 97 to the same as his background.  

I had to change `operatorcolor` and `parametercolor` from 90 to to 97 because in some of Microsoft's hosts 90 is a bit short of contrast . The old console host, the New Windows Terminal and VSCode all have their own definitions of what (e.g.) Yellow should be

comments.author: MAdrianMattocks
comments.body:
Went with the Gordian Knot solution. Deleted the `Computer\HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Console` registry key.

Sorry I didn't think of it sooner. Thanks for your help.

comments.author: MAdrianMattocks
comments.body: Here's an added piece of information. After I deleted the registry key I clicked the taskbar shortcut that I added after installing PowerShell. The issue remained but when I deleted the taskbar shortcut and clicked the shortcut in the Start Menu the problem was gone. No idea what to make of that but if someone finds this later, this is how I fixed it.
